p: In the case of one patch, the graph of R 0 is represented in Fig. 1a. For two patches, if m 12 = m 21, the value of the basic reproduction number doubles. When m 12 ≠ m 21, we set m 12 = α m 21 and substituted it in Eq. ( 3) and then-plotted R 0 in three dimensions as presented in Fig. 1b. The result of the simulation was quite interesting as highlighted herein. In Fig. 1b, it was observed that as the ratio of the migration between the two patches increases, the basic reproduction number decreases up to a threshold value α = 5. Furthermore, an increase of the value of α does not change the value of R 0. In this circumstance, the numerical value of R 0 obtained when α > 5 (i.e. where the basic reproduction number converge) is identical to the value estimated by Ross–Macdonald model with a single patch. When α = 1, the basic reproduction number is the double of the critical value of R 0 obtained at α > 5.
